>From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>

>[I suggested adding a random number to every neurone's output value...]
>
> >Ian,
> >
> >Adding it at the output means the ANN would never have the advantage of
> >attenuating its responses
> >to it, thereby missing the adaptive value add of becoming more robust to
> >noisy inputs, right?
>
>Maybe, but I guess I'm suggesting a sightly different approach.
>
>E.g. I'm not saying make randomness available to the network, I'm saying
>make a network that is inherently (a little) noisy.
>
>e.g the activation function becomes something like:
>
>val = Sigmoid(total) + RangedRand(-0.001, 0.001)

That is one way.  The down side is you have hard-coded random number range.  
NEAT has nothing but excessive topology at its disposal as a way of 
attenuating or amplifying it.

Making randomness available to it works almost as well.  Suppose that 
'total' includes a random component.  That random component is accomplished 
by recording a connection between the node and a 'magic' input.  Every time 
that input is accessed, it returns a different value.  So if 10 hidden nodes 
all have a connection to the same 'random' node, they still all get a 
different value from it.  Now, the random component is in the 'total', and 
the scale of that random component is able to be controled by manipulating 
the connection weight, something NEAT already does.

Add one more 'feature':  When a connection is split forming a new node, an 
additional connection is immediately formed connecting the node to the 
random input.  So EVERY node has a random component, always.  Of course, you 
would have to code for the special case of splitting the connection to the 
random input node... :)

>I suggest this because:
>
>(i) the presence of randomness, averaged over many generations, can smooth
>the fitness landscape

Or over many activations, or over many test samples.

>(ii) a system evolved in the presence of randoness *within* the neurones
>will have been forced to be robust w.r.t other sorts of randomness
>(discuss, 10 points, show your working)

That was my point...discussed previously.  See example of walking on 
gravel...

>(iii) if the network can exploit randomness (e.g. in game playing where
>being unpredictable -- within constrains -- is an advantage) then it merely
>needs to amplify up some of it's own noise.  And, because the noise is
>available on every neurone, there's complete choice over what kind of noise
>it amplifies (e.g. it could apply far more noise to evaluating pawn moves
>than king moves...)

Which is much easier if all it has to do is manipulate the weight of a 
connection to a special input node.  Try and picture what NEAT would have to 
do in order to make two nodes, one returning a larger random number than the 
other...

>p.s.    there's a whole other discussion here, about whether the TWEANN
>community should still use a neurone design which was essentially enforced
>historically by the mathematical requirements of back-propagation, but it's
>a long and complex discussion

As long as Sigmoids work, I guess there's no harm or rush to change it.  But 
I'd be open to changing it, too...
